terms.name: contact affiliation
terms.value: Max Planck Institute for Biomedical Research Bioanalytical Mass Spectrometry Unit Röntgenstr. 20 48149 Münster Germany

description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the most frequent demyelinating disease and despite significant advances in the immunotherapy, disease progression still cannot be prevented. Promotion of remyelination, an endogenous repair process, represents a promising new treatment approach. However, spontaneous remyelination frequently fails in MS lesions due to an impaired differentiation of progenitor cells into mature, myelinating oligodendrocytes. Intrinsic oligodendroglial and extrinsic inflammatory factors may contribute to this differentiation block. Therefore, we compared induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived oligodendrocytes (hiOL) from MS patients and healthy controls as well as their response to extrinsic factors. While functional capabilities or proteome compostion of both cell types were virtually indistinguishable, we discovered that Interferon-gamma (IFNÎ³) producing immune cells significantly impaired oligodendroglial differentiation and observed no differences in the functional capabilities or the proteome. In summary, these data indicate that the oligodendroglial differentiation block is not due to intrinsic oligodendroglial factors, but rather caused by the inflammatory environment present in MS lesions. These findings may contribute to the development of remyelination promoting strategies in MS.

keywords.name: submitter keyword
keywords.value: Induced pluripotent stem cells, oligodendrocytes, proteomics, mass spectrometry, relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis, remyelination, IFNγ

terms.name: Reference
terms.value: Starost L, Lindner M, Herold M, Xu YKT, Drexler HCA, Heß K, Ehrlich M, Ottoboni L, Ruffini F, Stehling M, Röpke A, Thomas C, Schöler HR, Antel J, Winkler J, Martino G, Klotz L, Kuhlmann T. Extrinsic immune cell-derived, but not intrinsic oligodendroglial factors contribute to oligodendroglial differentiation block in multiple sclerosis. Acta Neuropathol. 2020

title: Extrinsic inflammatory, but not intrinsic oligodendroglial factors contribute to oligodendroglial differentiation block in multiple sclerosis
